xxl.core.math.statistics.nonparametric.kernels

Class KernelBandwidths

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.math.statistics.nonparametric.kernels.KernelBandwidths

  • public class KernelBandwidths
extends Object
    One main problem of nonparametric statistics is the estimation of the probability density function (pdf) of a random variable. The estimation typically relies on a given sample, in our case data given by objects of type Number. For density estimation kernel based techniques are quite robust and useful. There, for each data point X_i a kernel is centered at X_i. Then, the sum is built over all kernels. The kernel density estimator inherits the basic properties of the kernel function. For this function different choices are possible whereas a pdf is advisable (that is restricted to [-1,1] in our case). The mostly used kernels are positive and symmetric with a compact support, e.g., the Epanechnikow kernel or the Gaussian kernel. The choice of the bandwidth h, which controls the degree of smoothness, is crucial for the quality of the estimation. There is a trade-off in choosing the bandwidth. If h is too high, the resulting estimate is smooth and may hide local features of the density. For a small bandwidth, the estimate will be spiky and artificial artifacts may be introduced.
    If the primitive of the kernel is known, this approach can be extended towards the estimation of the cumulative distribution function (cdf) by simply integrating the kernel based density estimator appropriately.
    Besides these applications estimators based on kernels may also be applicable in other scenarios. Again, the choice of the bandwidth is crucial for the quality of these estimators.
    This class provides some static methods for dealing with bandwidths for kernel estimators. Since there are many choices for bandwiths we refer for a more detailed coverage to
    [Sco92]: David W. Scott. Multivariate Density Estimation: Theory, Practice, and Visualization. 1992 and
    [WJ95]: M.P. Wand and M.C. Jones. Kernel Smoothing. 1995. pages 60 ff.
    See Also:
    AbstractKernelDensityEstimator, AbstractKernelCDF, KernelFunction

    • Method Detail

      • computeBandWidth1D

        public static double computeBandWidth1D(int type,
                                        Object[] sample,
                                        KernelFunction kf,
                                        double var,
                                        double min,
                                        double max)
        Computes the bandwidth of a specified type for a given kernel estimator. The kernel estimator relies on a sample and a kernel function with a known variance.
        Parameters:
        type - bandwidth strategy
        sample - used sample to compute the estimation. Given as Objects of type Number.
        kf - kernel function
        var - variance of the kernel function
        min - minimum of the data
        max - maximum of the data
        Returns:
        bandwidth according to the chosen strategy

      • oversmoothingRule

        public static double oversmoothingRule(int n,
                                       double var,
                                       double r,
                                       double s)
        Computes a one-dimensional bandwidth for a kernel estimator based upon the oversmoothing or maximal principle rule. For further informations see [WJ95]: M.P. Wand and M.C. Jones. Kernel Smoothing. Chapman & Hall. 1995. pages 60 ff.
        Parameters:
        n - size of the used sample
        var - variance of the used kernel function.
        r - R value (roughness) of the used kernel function. ( R(f) = integral( f(x)^2 dx) ). See [Sco92] page 281 (notation).
        s - estimator for the spread of the data, e.g., an estimator for the standard deviation or the inter quartil range of the data
        Returns:
        bandwidth computed with the oversmoothing rule
        See Also:
        KernelFunction.r(), KernelFunction.variance(), NativeKernelDensityEstimator

      • oversmoothingRule

        public static double oversmoothingRule(int n,
                                       KernelFunction kf,
                                       double s)
        Computes a one-dimensional bandwidth for a kernel estimator based upon the oversmoothing oder maximal principle rule. For further informations see [WJ95]: M.P. Wand and M.C. Jones. Kernel Smoothing. Chapman & Hall. 1995. pages 60 ff.
        Parameters:
        n - size of the used sample
        kf - Used kernel function
        s - estimator for the spread of the data, e.g., an estimator for the variance or the inter quartil range of the data
        Returns:
        a bandwidth computed with the oversmoothing rule
        See Also:
        KernelFunction, NativeKernelDensityEstimator

      • normalScaleRule

        public static double normalScaleRule(int n,
                                     double var,
                                     double r,
                                     double s)
        Computes a one-dimensional bandwidth for a kernel estimator based upon the normal scale rule. For further informations see [Sco92]: David W. Scott. Multivariate Density Estimation: Theory, Practice, and Visualization. John Wiley & Sons, inc. 1992. pages 131 ff. The normal scale rule is also known as thumb rule.
        Parameters:
        n - size of the used sample
        var - variance of the used kernel function
        r - R value (roughness) of the used kernel function. ( R(f) = integral( f(x)^2 dx) ). See [Sco92] page 281 (notation)
        s - estimator for the spread of the data, e.g., an estimator for the standard deviation or the inter quartil range of the data
        Returns:
        a bandwidth computed with the normal scale rule
        See Also:
        KernelFunction.r(), KernelFunction.variance(), NativeKernelDensityEstimator

      • normalScaleRule

        public static double normalScaleRule(int n,
                                     KernelFunction kf,
                                     double s)
        Computes a one-dimensional bandwidth for a kernel estimator based upon the normal scale rule. For further informations see
        [Sco92]: David W. Scott. Multivariate Density Estimation: Theory, Practice, and Visualization. John Wiley & Sons, inc. 1992. pages 131 ff.
        The normal scale rule is also known as thumb rule.
        Parameters:
        n - size of the used sample
        kf - Used kernel function
        s - estimator for the spread of the data, e.g., an estimator for the variance or the inter quartil range of the data
        Returns:
        a bandwidth computed with the normal scale rule
        See Also:
        KernelFunction, NativeKernelDensityEstimator

      • adaBand

        public static double[] adaBand(Object[] sample,
                               Iterator data,
                               Distance distance,
                               int quantil)
        Computes the bandwidths for each given sample value (equally for each dimension) as the distance of the k-nearest neighbour of the sample values wrt. the given entirety.
        Based upon [DG01]: Domeniconi, Carlotta. Gunopulos, Dimitios. An Efficent Approach for Approximation Multi-dimensional Range Queries and Nearest Neighbor Classification in Large Datasets. 2001
        Parameters:
        sample - Object [] containing a sample with values of type double []
        data - iterator delivering the entirety of the given sample
        distance - distance function
        quantil - use the distance of the quantil-nearest neighbuor to a sample value for bandwidth
        Returns:
        the bandwidths (equally for each dimension) of the corresponding sample values

      • scottsRule

        public static double[] scottsRule(double[] stdDev,
                                  int n)
        Returns the bandwidths for a n-dimensional kernel estimator based upon Scott's rule. For further informations see
        [Sco92]: David W. Scott. Multivariate Density Estimation: Theory, Practice, and Visualization. John Wiley & Sons, inc. 1992. pages 131 ff.
        Parameters:
        stdDev - standard deviations of the data in the corresponding dimensions
        n - sample size used for estimation
        Returns:
        array of type double[] containing the bandwidths for the corresponding dimensions

      • maximumLikelihoodCV

        public static double maximumLikelihoodCV(Object[] sample,
                                         KernelFunction kf,
                                         double h)
        Computes a one-dimensional bandwidth for a kernel estimator based upon the maximum likelihood cross validation. For further informations see [Har91]: W. Hardle. Smoothing techniques with implementation in S. 1991.
        Parameters:
        sample - used sample of the data given by Objects of type Number.
        kf - used kernel function
        h - used bandwidth for cross validation
        Returns:
        a bandwidth computed with maximum likelihood cross validation.

      • maximumLikelihoodCV

        public static double[] maximumLikelihoodCV(Object[] sample,
                                           KernelFunction kf,
                                           double[] hs)
        Computes a d-dimensional bandwidth for a kernel estimator based upon the maximum likelihood cross validation. For further informations see [Har91]: W. Hardle. Smoothing techniques with implementation in S. 1991.
        Parameters:
        sample - used sample of the data given by Objects of type Number.
        kf - used kernel function
        hs - used bandwidths for cross validation for the corresponding dimension
        Returns:
        bandwidths computed with maximum likelihood cross validation.

      • directNSPlugInRule2Stage

        public static double directNSPlugInRule2Stage(Object[] sample,
                                              int n,
                                              KernelFunction kf,
                                              double s)
        Computes a one-dimensional bandwidth for a kernel estimator based upon the 2-stage direct plug in rule using a normal kernel function for estimating the roughness of the plug-in values. For further informations see [WJ95]: M.P. Wand and M.C. Jones. Kernel Smoothing. Chapman & Hall. 1995. pages 71 ff.
        Parameters:
        sample - used sample of the data given by Objects of type Number
        n - size of the used sample
        kf - used kernel function
        s - estimator for the spread of the data, e.g., an estimator for the standard deviation or the inter quartil range of the data
        Returns:
        bandwidth computed with the 2-stage direct plug in rule

      • directNSPlugInRule2Stage

        public static double directNSPlugInRule2Stage(Object[] sample,
                                              int n,
                                              double var,
                                              double r,
                                              double s)
        Computes a one-dimensional bandwidth for a kernel estimator based upon the 2-stage direct plug in rule using a normal kernel function for estimating the roughness of the plug-in values. For further informations see [WJ95]: M.P. Wand and M.C. Jones. Kernel Smoothing. Chapman & Hall. 1995. pages 71 ff.
        Parameters:
        sample - used sample of the data given by Objects of type Number
        n - size of the used sample
        var - variance of the used kernel function.
        r - R value (roughness) of the used kernel function. ( R(f) = integral( f(x)^2 dx) ). See [Sco92] page 281 (notation).
        s - estimator for the spread of the data, e.g., an estimator for the standard deviation or the inter quartil range of the data.
        Returns:
        bandwidth computed with the 2-stage direct plug in rule
